_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: All Other Chemical Product and Preparation Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



As a Responsible Care(R) 14001 certified facility, the employees of Renessenz, LLC Jacksonville facility are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes, especially those using hazardous substances, in a safe and responsible manner.  A combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs is used to ensure the safety of  employees and the public as well as the protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that  have been designed and implemented, including:



    A description of the facility and use of substances regulated by EPA's RMP regulation

    A summary of results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences from accidental chemical releases

    An overview of accidental release prevention programs

    A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals regulated by EPA's RMP rule

    An overview of the emergency response program

    An overview of planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public, and the environment

    Certification by company official





STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



The Jacksonville facility produces aroma and flavor chemicals using a variety of chemicals and processing operations.  The facility consists of 54 acres in a predominantly residential and commercial neighborhood. The main processes are distillation and reactions. The chemicals in use that EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release, are as follows:



Toxics:



Hydrogen Chloride (anhydrous)





KEY OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS SCENARIOS



Renessenz has provided a worst-case scenario and an alternate scenario for off-site consequences of an emergency event involving

hydrogen chloride or phosphorous trichloride.  This information is shared with authorized individuals involved in emergency planning activities.  The worst-case scenario was developed in accordance with stipulations of the RMP (EPA) regulation; Renessenz considers the worst-case scenario and the predicted consequences to be extremely unlikely.  The alternate scenario presented is also very unlikely but predicts impacts for a loss of hazardous material containment with mitigating equipment and procedures activated.





GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



Accidental release prevention programs and contingency planning efforts help the facility to effectively manage the hazards that are posed to employees, the public, and the environment.



The facility maintains several programs and practices designed to minimize the possibility of accidental releases and ensure safe operation.  The accident prevention programs in place include:



Integrated Contingency Plan, which includes the company emergency plan 

Inspections, Testing and Preventative Maintenance

Incident Investigations

Employee Training and Process Operating Procedures

Hazardous Work Permit Procedures

Formal Process Hazard Analysis 

Management of Change and Pre-Start-up Safety Reviews

Contractor Safety Program

Process Design Following Generally Accepted Good Engineering Practices



Specific additional methods employed to prevent accidental release of hydrogen chloride include leak detection sensors and alarms in the processing and storage areas, automation and process interlocks, water spray nozzles at the connection between the process piping and bulk storage, automatic shutdown of the hydrogen chloride supply upon process upset or leak detection, flow-limiting valve to limit and minimize gas flow out of bulk storage, and a caustic scrubber to neutralize any vapors from the process equipment.





FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no sig

nificant releases of hydrogen chloride in the last five years while working with smaller stored quantities of hydrogen chloride. No incident resulted in significant company property damage, employee injury or off-site impact to people, property or the environment.





EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The facility maintains an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state and local regulatory requirements for  emergency response planning. The program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting the employees, the public and the environment during emergency conditions. The plan is available to the Local Emergency Planning Committee, Federal authorities, Florida Division of Emergency Management, City of Jacksonville and to local responders for coordination with the community emergency plans.





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The facility has a systematic program for reviewing process hazards and as improvements are identified as worthwhile, they will be implemented.  All employees actively participate in the identification of potential safety issues and opportunities for improvement.  Observations, recommendations and concerns submitted by employees are tracked and addressed as part of a continuous improvement system.





CERTIFICATION



To the best of the my knowledge, information, and belief formed after reasonable inquiry, the information submitted in this Risk Management Plan is true, accurate, and complete.



Certifying Official:  Brenda S. Murray, Director Regulatory Affairs, Pinova Holdings, Inc.
